>There were no Mysteries in the beginning, we are taught. Knowledge (Vidyā) was common property, and it reigned universally throughout the Golden Age (Satya Yuga). As says the Commentary:

>Men had not created evil yet in those days of bliss and purity, for they were of God-like more than of human nature.
But when mankind, rapidly increasing in numbers, increased also in variety of idiosyncrasies of body and mind, then incarnated Spirit showed its weakness. Natural exaggerations, and along with these superstitions, arose in the less cultured and healthy minds. Selfishness was born out of desires and passions hitherto unknown, and but too often knowledge and power were abused, until finally it became necessary to limit the number of those who knew. Thus arose Initiation.

>Every separate nation now arranged for itself a religious system, according to its enlightenment and spiritual wants. Worship of mere form being discarded by the wise men, these confined true knowledge to the very few. The need of veiling truth to protect it from desecration becoming more apparent with every generation, a thin veil was used at first, which had to be gradually thickened according to the spread of personality and selfishness, and this led to the Mysteries. They came to be established in every country and among every people, while to avoid strife and misunderstanding exoteric beliefs were allowed to grow up in the minds of the profane masses. Inoffensive and innocent in their incipient stage—like a historical event arranged in the form of a fairy tale, adapted for and comprehensible to the child’s mind—in those distant ages such beliefs could be allowed to grow and make the popular faith without any danger to the more philosophical and abstruse truths taught in the sanctuaries.”

— H.P. Blavatsky, The Origin of the Mysteries

As one enters the Well of Dreams, they are greeted by a warning: "You have found the well of dreams but you will never find the Tunnel City." This cryptic message is said to hint at the existence of a hidden community of outcasts who live within the tunnels, choosing to remain hidden from the outside world. >>33785191
I used to work for Con Edison back in the 90s before I changed to sanitation. I had to change jobs because it was too fucking freaky down there.

New York City has hundreds, maybe even thousands of miles of tunnels. Some of which go back all the to the fucking 1800s.

We found all kinds of shit down there, bodies, animals, a fucking bear once. Entire fucking homeless cities with dozens of people living there.

I've seen and heard the weirdest shit you couldn't imagine. I'll never go back down into the maintenance tunnels again after this one time.

I was working on a route under the lower east side, right outside of downtown. It has one of the highest rates of shit breaking going on down there because all the businesses and huge homes and condos. They put such a tremendous strain on the system, there are constant fires and outages.

We were really deep in the old tunnels where the walls are sandstone bricks from the early 1900s, everything is brass and the wires are covered in thick heavy coating, almost like cardboard. At the time, all the main wires had not been replaced, yet.

I was pulling down a junction box with my buddy, and we both heard this fucking low pitch guttural sound, like a cat throwing up, but long like a growl. So we stop and look, cause there are feral animals down there, and the rats are fucking huge. They're a serious threat.

We turn and look down the corridor into the darkness, and there's this fucking creature standing there at the turn. Maybe 4 feet tall, extremely thin and gangly looking. Its eyes were bright orange in my headlamp. It was standing there in the corner just watching us, pacing back and forth and growling.

My friend and I fucking ran out of there so god damn fast I tore my ankle slipping up the catwalk into the main tunnel. Two months later I transferred to sanitation with DSNY. Never fucking looked back.

I'm 61 now, about to retire. I'm planning to move out of New York into the rural area of Pennsylvania.
